awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Optimization-driven high-density air traffic management software for large-scale drone operations
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to develop technology to make the low-altitude airspace more accessible for commercial drone delivery operations while ensuring a high level of operational safety and efficiency. Large-scale, organized deployment of delivery drones can unlock substantial efficiency gain in transportation systems in terms of reduced road congestion, reduced CO2 emission; in addition, it would offer health and convenience benefits to senior citizens, the ill, and mobility-challenged members of society. However, existing drone delivery practices are limited in scope, scale, and operating conditions due to inefficient air traffic management (ATM) paradigms. This project aims to discover a viable business model for translating technological innovations in unmanned ATM into an operable, city-scale, fully automated drone delivery system. The proposed system would allow safe use of the low-altitude airspace at an unprecedented density and efficiency, generating enormous savings for last-mile deliveries. 

This I-Corps project explores the development of a suite of novel optimization-driven algorithms in the areas of motion-planning, dynamic vehicle routing, communication and risk minimization to provide real-time ATM and trajectory control for a cooperative fleet of drones navigating a shared airspace. Existing ATM methods leave excessive separation margins due to human-level response time and control dexterity. In contrast, the proposed new system is optimized for high-density air traffic conditions, offering the capability to generate real-time adjustments to 4D flight trajectories, tolerating a smaller separation margin, and overseeing safe execution of control commands across the fleet. In a plug-and-play fashion, the proposed system will turn a collection of heterogeneous multicopter drones into an organized and intelligent fleet. The competitive advantage lies in the fusion of the state-of-the-art operations research (OR) models and algorithms onto drone platforms via commoditized cloud computing, IoT and communication infrastructures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of the project was to discover a pathway for translating optimization-driven high-density air traffic management (UTM) algorithms into a viable business model. A critical first step is understanding who will benefit from this technology, who will pay for it and how much they are willing to pay. A secondary goal was to gather practical insights, including previously overlooked pain points of drone users and new use cases, to direct future R&D and commercialization endeavors.

Through customer interviews, site visits, community engagement and tradeshows, the team has gathered tremendous first-hand information about the UTM ecosystem, and tested many hypotheses about technology readiness, value proposition, and customer segments. The team interviewed more than 100 people that were hypothesized to play key roles in the drone delivery ecosystem, if one was established. Here are some key findings. 1. For small drones, while the cost of electric energy consumed in a short flight is almost negligible, the flight’s share of the battery’s acquisition and maintenance costs is not. Barring a new breakthrough in battery technology (or alternative power source technology), efficient fleet-level battery management will be the key factor that determines the bottom line of a drone-based delivery business. 2. The DJI drones and software suites have been predominantly used in production and revenue-generating missions of small multirotor aircraft, in spite of federal and state level rulemaking movements against foreign-made drones. 3. The need for optimization (of drone traffic) in the context of USS interoperability is lukewarm. One reason is the lack of a standard cost model for the use of low-altitude airspace.

This I-Corps project provided the entrepreneurial lead (EL) in-depth knowledge of the lean startup process. The EL used the learning to build and grow a team and launched Litter-Robot 4, a new generation of self-cleaning litter box for pets. This project has led the EL to pursue an entrepreneurial career where he worked with several startups in various roles. Customer discovery activities and findings enabled the technical lead (TL) to better align his R&D efforts with market needs. The TL learned to ask the right questions and focus on customer discovery before any product development. The Co-TL obtained his PhD degree with support of this project and landed his first job as R&D scientist in an insurance firm. The industrial mentor launched his own startup company in a different area (K-12 student transportation) and continued practicing the I-Corps mindsets and techniques, including doing the job of driving a bus for 6 weeks to understand customer needs and pain points.


Last Modified: 01/31/2024
Modified by: Yanchao Liu
